newsitem.title: COTE D'IVOIRE: New Air Afrique management takes over in February.
newsitem.headline: New Air Afrique management takes over in February.

text.p: Air Afrique shareholders met on Monday and put back until February 17 top management changes agreed earlier this year to set the struggling multi-national carrier back on its feet.
A statement from the company said that French chairman and managing director Yves-Roland Billecart would continue to run the airline until then.
The 11 member states selected the boss of Air Mauritius, Sir Harry K. Tirvengadum, to run the airline on November 11.

Monday's statement said the shareholders had "put back" the nomination of administrators to their next meeting on February 17 when a new board would formally consider the nomination of the new managing director and elect a new chairman.
"The general assembly (of shareholders) reaffirmed the pertinence of the elements of company's revival plan which must be considered major targets," the statement said.
A communique in November announced plans to create a special company to take over responsibility for planes at the root of Air Afrique's debt problem before the end of the year.
Each member will provide one billion CFA of the capital with ASECNA-Service, a subsidiary of the multinational Francophone African air safety agency ASECNA, providing 20 billion CFA.
Air Afrique's owners see the airline, which was set up in 1961 during the heady days that followed independence from France, as a symbol of inter-African cooperation.
They cut short Billecart's mandate after staff blamed him for the company's problems.
Air Afrique is majority owned by Benin, Burkina Faso, Chad, Central African Republic, Congo, Ivory Coast, Mauritania, Mali, Niger, Senegal and Togo. Air France is among stake holders.
